hypotheses.title: DNS Tunneling via nslookup in ClickFix Social Engineering Attacks
hypotheses.description: Attackers have evolved the ClickFix technique to abuse nslookup for DNS-based malware staging. Instead of relying on PowerShell or mshta (now commonly blocked), threat actors trick users into running nslookup commands that query custom DNS domains to retrieve encoded payloads. This method leverages legitimate Windows tools and blends into normal DNS traffic, making it harder to detect.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell

data_sources_needed.specific_data: DNS query logs, especially long subdomain queries with unusual patterns (e.g., base64-encoded strings, high entropy), nslookup command execution events
tools: DNS logs (e.g., BIND, Cisco Umbrella), EDR (e.g., CrowdStrike, SentinelOne), SIEM (e.g., Splunk, Sentinel)

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process creation logs for nslookup.exe, command-line arguments, parent-child process relationships
tools: Windows Event Logs (Event ID 4688), EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 1)

hunting_tactics.description: Search for nslookup.exe execution with suspicious arguments, especially those containing encoded data or unusual flags.
sample_queries: index=wineventlog EventCode=4688 ProcessName="*\\nslookup.exe" AND (CommandLine="* *.*" OR CommandLine="* -q=* *" OR CommandLine="* -type=* *")
index=sysmon EventID=1 Image="*\\nslookup.exe" AND NOT (CommandLine="* -q=TXT *" OR CommandLine="* -q=A *" OR CommandLine="* localhost")
hunting_tactics.look_for: nslookup.exe executed with non-standard arguments (e.g., custom DNS queries to suspicious domains, base64-encoded subdomains, or repeated queries to high-entropy domains)

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect DNS queries with high-entropy subdomains
hunting_tactics.description: Look for DNS queries with unusually long, random-looking subdomains that may indicate encoded payload exfiltration or staging.
sample_queries: index=dns_logs NOT (qname="*.microsoft.com" OR qname="*.google.com" OR qname="*.cloudflare.com") AND len(split(qname, '.')) > 3 AND regex(qname, "^[a-f0-9]{32,}")
index=dns_logs qname="*.nslookup[.]xyz" OR qname="*.clickfix[.]top" OR qname="*.update[.]in" OR qname="*.patch[.]in"
hunting_tactics.look_for: DNS queries with subdomains containing 30+ character alphanumeric strings, especially those matching known malicious TLDs or patterns from recent campaigns

network_patterns: High-frequency DNS queries to single domain in short time window
DNS queries with TXT/NULL record types to suspicious domains
other_indicators: nslookup.exe spawned by cmd.exe or powershell.exe with suspicious parent-child chain
DNS queries to domains registered within last 30 days

recommended_actions: Block DNS queries to newly registered domains with high-entropy subdomains
Alert on nslookup.exe execution with non-default arguments
Review user sessions where nslookup.exe was executed via social engineering (e.g., fake CAPTCHA prompts)
Correlate with endpoint telemetry to identify initial ClickFix诱饵 (e.g., fake update notifications, browser crashes)

hypotheses.title: AI Assistant Abuse as Malware C2 Proxy via Web Browsing Features
hypotheses.description: AI assistants like Microsoft Copilot and xAI Grok, when configured with web browsing capabilities, can be abused to relay C2 traffic. Attackers craft prompts that cause the AI to fetch malicious payloads from attacker-controlled servers, blending C2 communication into legitimate-looking traffic to evade network detection.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
T1559.002 - Inter-Process Communication: Dynamic Data Exchange

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS traffic to AI service endpoints (e.g., copilot.microsoft.com, grok.com) with anomalous payload patterns, TLS SNI mismatches, or unexpected POST/GET parameters
tools: TLS inspection logs, proxy logs (e.g., Prisma Access, Zscaler), SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Process execution of AI assistant clients (e.g., copilot.exe, grok.exe), API calls to web-browsing features, screenshot or clipboard capture events
tools: EDR (e.g., CrowdStrike, SentinelOne), Windows Event Logs, PowerShell scriptblock logging

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Detect AI assistant web-browsing activity with suspicious payloads
hunting_tactics.description: Search for AI assistant processes making HTTP/HTTPS requests to non-standard URLs or with large, encoded payloads in responses.
sample_queries: index=proxy_logs (user_agent="*Copilot*" OR user_agent="*Grok*" OR user_agent="*BingBot*" OR user_agent="*Googlebot*") AND (uri_path="*/api/v1/fetch" OR uri_path="*/proxy" OR uri_path="*/web-search") AND response_size > 50000

index=endpoint_events (process_name="copilot.exe" OR process_name="grok.exe" OR process_name="msedge.exe" AND command_line="*--copilot*") AND (network_connection="*" AND NOT (domain="*.microsoft.com" OR domain="*.x.ai" OR domain="*.bing.com"))
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI assistant processes making outbound requests to domains not in their official allowlist, especially with large base64-encoded responses or unexpected JSON payloads

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Monitor for clipboard/data exfiltration to AI assistants
hunting_tactics.description: Look for processes that copy sensitive data to the clipboard and then trigger AI assistant web-browsing features.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventID=10 AND (TargetObject="*Clipboard*" OR TargetObject="*CF_TEXT*" OR TargetObject="*CF_UNICODETEXT*") AND (Image="*\\python.exe" OR Image="*\\node.exe" OR Image="*\\powershell.exe")

index=endpoint_events (process_name="copilot.exe" OR process_name="grok.exe") AND (command_line="*summarize*" OR command_line="*fetch*" OR command_line="*generate*" OR command_line="*analyze*") AND (command_line="*http*" OR command_line="*https*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: AI assistant processes invoked with commands to summarize, fetch, or analyze URLs or clipboard content, especially when preceded by suspicious data access events

network_patterns: HTTPS to AI service domains with POST payloads > 10KB
TLS handshakes to AI domains with unusual certificate chains
other_indicators: AI assistant processes spawned by suspicious parent processes (e.g., cmd.exe, powershell.exe)
Clipboard access events followed by AI assistant invocation

recommended_actions: Restrict AI assistant web-browsing permissions via group policy or endpoint controls
Alert on AI assistant processes making outbound requests to non-whitelisted domains
Monitor for clipboard-to-AI data flows using EDR telemetry
Review user sessions where AI assistants were invoked with commands to process URLs or clipboard content

hypotheses.title: OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Theft via Infostealers
hypotheses.description: Infostealers have evolved to target OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot/Moltbot) configuration files and gateway tokens, which contain API keys, authentication tokens, and agent settings. This allows attackers to hijack victims' AI agent identities and access sensitive data or systems the agent is authorized to interact with.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files

data_sources_needed.specific_data: File system access events to OpenClaw directories (e.g., ~/.clawdbot, ~/.openclaw), process execution of known infostealers (e.g., LummaStealer, RedLine)
tools: EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 11/15), Windows Event Logs

data_sources_needed.specific_data: API key usage anomalies, token refresh events from unusual locations, OpenClaw gateway authentication failures
tools: CloudTrail, Azure AD Audit Logs, Okta logs

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Search for OpenClaw configuration file access
hunting_tactics.description: Look for processes accessing OpenClaw configuration directories or files, especially from non-OpenClaw processes.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventID=11 TargetFilename="*\\.clawdbot*" OR TargetFilename="*\\.openclaw*" OR TargetFilename="*\\clawdbot*" OR TargetFilename="*\\openclaw*"

index=endpoint_events (process_name="lumma.exe" OR process_name="redline.exe" OR process_name="stealc.exe" OR process_name="qakbot.exe") AND (file_access="*\\.clawdbot*" OR file_access="*\\.openclaw*" OR file_access="*\\clawdbot*" OR file_access="*\\openclaw*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Infostealer processes accessing directories like ~/.clawdbot, ~/.openclaw, or files named config.json, gateway_tokens.json, or api_keys.json

hunting_tactics.description: Identify unusual authentication patterns for OpenClaw gateway services, such as multiple failed logins or logins from new IP ranges.
sample_queries: index=cloud_logs (event_source="openclaw" OR event_source="clawdbot") AND (event_type="authentication_failure" OR event_type="token_refresh") AND (source_ip="*" AND NOT (source_ip IN ("10.0.0.0/8", "192.168.0.0/16", "172.16.0.0/12")))

index=identity_logs (service="openclaw" OR service="clawdbot") AND (authentication_status="failure" AND count(*) > 5) AND (user_agent="*curl*" OR user_agent="*wget*" OR user_agent="*python-requests*")
hunting_tactics.look_for: Multiple failed authentication attempts to OpenClaw gateway, especially from non-corporate IP ranges or using non-browser user agents

network_patterns: HTTPS to clawdbot/openclaw domains with POST requests containing base64-encoded payloads
other_indicators: OpenClaw gateway authentication from new geographic locations
API key usage spikes in non-business hours

recommended_actions: Revoke all OpenClaw API keys and tokens for affected users
Audit OpenClaw gateway access logs for unauthorized sessions
Block outbound connections to clawdbot/openclaw domains unless explicitly required
Enable MFA for all OpenClaw gateway access

hypotheses.title: Supply Chain Compromise via Notepad++ Update Mechanism
hypotheses.description: Attackers compromised Notepad++'s update infrastructure to deliver targeted malware by intercepting update traffic before it reached users. This supply chain attack leveraged infrastructure-level compromise rather than code-level flaws, making it difficult to detect without integrity checks on updates.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain

data_sources_needed.specific_data: HTTPS traffic to notepad-plus-plus.org, update checksum mismatches, certificate anomalies
tools: TLS inspection logs, proxy logs, SIEM

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Notepad++ process execution, update file hashes, registry entries for update source
tools: EDR, Sysmon (Event ID 1/15), Windows Event Logs

hunting_tactics.description: Search for Notepad++ installations where update checksums or signatures do not match official releases.
sample_queries: index=sysmon EventID=15 TargetFilename="*\\notepad++\\plugins\\*" OR TargetFilename="*\\notepad++\\updater\\*" AND (Hash="*" AND NOT (Hash IN ("abc123...", "def456...")))

index=endpoint_events (process_name="notepad++.exe" OR process_name="updater.exe") AND (file_path="*\\notepad++\\updater\\*" OR file_path="*\\notepad++\\plugins\\*") AND (file_hash="*" AND NOT (file_hash IN ("abc123...", "def456...")))
hunting_tactics.look_for: Notepad++ update files with hashes not matching official releases, especially those with suspicious file paths or names

hunting_tactics.description: Look for DNS or HTTP redirects to malicious update servers, or TLS certificates not issued by official CAs.
sample_queries: index=dns_logs qname="update.notepad-plus-plus.org" AND (answer="*malware*" OR answer="*evil*" OR answer="*attacker*")

index=proxy_logs (host="update.notepad-plus-plus.org" OR host="notepad-plus-plus.org") AND (tls_server_name="*notepad-plus-plus.org" AND NOT (tls_issuer="DigiCert Inc" OR tls_issuer="Sectigo Limited"))
hunting_tactics.look_for: DNS responses or TLS handshakes pointing to unexpected IPs or certificates not issued by DigiCert/Sectigo

network_patterns: HTTPS to notepad-plus-plus.org with TLS certificates not from DigiCert/Sectigo
DNS queries to notepad-plus-plus.org subdomains with high entropy
other_indicators: Notepad++ updates installed outside normal patch windows
Notepad++ processes spawned by suspicious parent processes

recommended_actions: Verify Notepad++ installations against official checksums
Block outbound connections to notepad-plus-plus.org unless explicitly required
Deploy EDR with update integrity monitoring
Review user sessions where Notepad++ was updated outside normal patch windows

hypotheses.title: Compromised Customer Contact Systems Leading to Mass Data Exfiltration
hypotheses.description: Multiple breaches (e.g., Odido, Betterment) involved attackers compromising customer contact systems to exfiltrate sensitive data. These systems often have elevated privileges and lack segmentation, allowing attackers to access large volumes of PII and financial data.
mitre_attack_techniques: T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares

data_sources_needed.specific_data: Unusual outbound data transfers to contact system IPs, database query patterns, API access logs
Privileged access to contact system accounts, unusual login locations/times, MFA bypass attempts

hunting_tactics.description: Search for unusual access patterns to customer contact systems, such as bulk data exports or API calls to sensitive endpoints.
sample_queries: index=contact_system_logs (action="export" OR action="bulk_query" OR action="api_call") AND (user="*" AND NOT (user IN ("admin", "support", "service_account"))) AND (timestamp > relative_time(now(), "-7d"))
index=identity_logs (service="contact_system" OR service="crm") AND (authentication_status="success" AND source_ip="*" AND NOT (source_ip IN ("10.0.0.0/8", "192.168.0.0/16", "172.16.0.0/12")))
hunting_tactics.look_for: Bulk data exports from contact systems, API calls to sensitive endpoints (e.g., /api/v1/customers/export), logins from new geographic locations

hunting_tactics.tactic_name: Monitor for credential stuffing in contact systems
hunting_tactics.description: Look for high volumes of authentication attempts or MFA bypass attempts targeting contact system accounts.
sample_queries: index=identity_logs (service="contact_system" OR service="crm") AND (authentication_status="failure" AND count(*) > 10) AND (user_agent="*curl*" OR user_agent="*python-requests*" OR user_agent="*Go-http-client*")
index=contact_system_logs (action="login" OR action="mfa_verify") AND (status="failure" AND count(*) > 5) AND (source_ip="*" AND NOT (source_ip IN ("10.0.0.0/8", "192.168.0.0/16", "172.16.0.0/12")))
hunting_tactics.look_for: Multiple failed login attempts to contact system accounts, especially from non-corporate IPs or with bot-like user agents

network_patterns: HTTPS to contact system IPs with large POST/GET payloads
DNS queries to contact system subdomains
other_indicators: Contact system access from new geographic locations
Bulk data exports outside business hours

recommended_actions: Isolate contact systems from general network access
Implement strict MFA and least-privilege access controls
Monitor for bulk data exports or API calls to sensitive endpoints
Review user sessions where contact systems were accessed outside normal business hours

unique_mitre_techniques: T1021.001 - Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
T1059.001 - Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell
T1559.002 - Inter-Process Communication: Dynamic Data Exchange
T1195.002 - Supply Chain Compromise: Compromise Software Supply Chain
T1552.001 - Unsecured Credentials: Credentials in Files
T1071.001 - Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
